body:
### Problem

After #25288, the following happens when `neovim` exits unsuccessfully:

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/62502207/f2613af3-2e0c-4d1c-afb3-1949869e4ca0

Below I show what happens when starting the lua debugger and then exiting with `:ZZ` (I guess this doesn't terminate the DAP session correctly). Notice how the GUI remains frozen at the top.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Use your following method to make Neovim exit with a failure status.
2. Notice the frozen UI.

### Expected behavior

For shutdown to complete on failure.

### Neovim version (nvim -v)

v0.10.0-dev-1177+gfcfc87cb7

### Vim (not Nvim) behaves the same?

N/A

### Operating system/version

Mac Ventura 13.5.2

### Terminal name/version

kitty 0.30

### $TERM environment variable

xterm-kitty

### Installation

From source

comment_data.body: log from console would be help

That isn't what this issue is about though. It is the strange frozen UI what I'm pointing out.
What is "your following method"?
@zeertzjq what do you mean?
Anyway, shutdown shouldn't complete on failure, because you need to know what the failure is.
@zeertzjq well the failure isn't even being displayed.

I still have to ask: What does this mean?
> Use your following method to make Neovim exit with a failure status.
@zeertzjq sorry for not being more specific about it. I'm creating a minimal configuration.

@zeertzjq wait did you [fix it](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/25313)? 
EDIT: Nvm, I can still repro it. Still working on the config...
Then this is the expected behavior, because otherwise you won't see the error message.

@zeertzjq I'm sorry to continue but I insist: It feels like one of the goals of https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/25288 was improving the diagnosing of crashes, yet I feel that this actually makes it worse? Moreover, the description of that PR said that "This change prevents this in the latter case (_this is what I'm describing in this issue_), while still cleaning up the terminal properly when :cquit was deliberatily invoked. Other cleanup like exiting mouse mode and raw mode is still done". It feels like that cleanup isn't happening anymore.
If you press Ctrl-C it cancels a command in the shell instead of producing an escape sequence it cannot recognize, so the cleanup was happening.
I never pressed Ctrl-C though. I exited Neovim using `ZZ`.

is it overwriting your shell's scrollback? otherwise it might actually be good. you can see what text you had open when neovim crashed

FWIW this is also how `git diff` behaves

well, it kinda has to in this simple implementation. The same command that would clear out the frozen UI would also clear out the error message.

The alternative, which I considered before but decided to wait with, was to let the TUI process buffer the stderr output and replay it _after_ restoring the screen. however, the very state of the screen might also provide hints of what went wrong in the first place. So I am inclined to agree that the "frozen UI" is a feature and not a bug in this case as well.

> The same command that would clear out the frozen UI would also clear out the error message.

I wish someone had said this before. It makes much more sense now.

> The alternative, which I considered before but decided to wait with, was to let the TUI process buffer the stderr output and replay it after restoring the screen. however, the very state of the screen might also provide hints of what went wrong in the first place. So I am inclined to agree that the "frozen UI" is a feature and not a bug in this case as well.

That's fair. Unfortunately I don't see an error message when shutting down the debugger or when experiencing #25145, so having Neovim crash like that felt like a regression, but what you explained makes sense.

>  Unfortunately I don't see an error message

I am still curious about this. it could be that it happens to be in some unfortunate place of the terminal, so it gets overwritten by the shell afterwards..

> I wish someone had said this before.

I was asleep when this issue was first opened and responded to, sorry :innocent:

> I am still curious about this. it could be that it happens to be in some unfortunate place of the terminal, so it gets overwritten by the shell afterwards..

If you really want to dig into it, I can build a "minimal" config with the DAP plugins I'm using. I can consistently reproduce it with that.

> I was asleep when this issue was first opened and responded to, sorry 😇

_smh_ How dare you sleep...

> If you really want to dig into it, I can build a "minimal" config with the DAP plugins I'm using. I can consistently reproduce it with that.

That would be helpful to resolve this issue, yes.
@bfredl hmm I'm struggling building the minimal config. I cannot repro it with just the DAP plugins, so it must be something else. Could the missing error message be caused by a plugin?

When happening with my full config, the logs do show that this is a `SIGBUS` error:
```
System Integrity Protection: enabled
```

ah, that might not show an error message regardless on mac os. The change https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/25288 was mainly for `assert()` or for ASAN where an error message is printed by the nvim process.

Oh I see...
Okay it seems like there's no problem here, so I'll close this for now.

@bfredl okay after debugging this for a bit I can see that the following was printed in `stderr`: `Assertion failed: (!uv__is_closing(handle)), function uv_close, file core.c, line 147.`.

However that doesn't seem to make it to the terminal...

title: TUI: issue with crash shutdown and kitty
